Posts.Content: Diagnosed March, 6 sessions of chemo, lumpectomy and finished radiotherapy December.  Thinking about returning to work.  Did private cleaning before all of this which I have decided to not go back as is physically hard work, 2 houses a day.   Just spent about an hour tidying my daughters bedroom as she has gone travelling, so good chance for a spring clean, and I'm exhausted and have back ache! Looking at maybe going back into admin work which is what I have done previously.  What sort of hours did people start off doing when returning to work?  Anyone found employers put off by the fact you have had cancer? I would be grateful for anyones experiences. Thank you, Alison x
Posts.Title: Returning to work? How soon?

Posts.Content: Hello Mine was the same as yours but 35mm. No lymph node involvement.  I waited 3 weeks before chemo  started and was worried but they reassured me if wouldn't grow that quickly. I had chemo first to shrink my lump and hopefully save the breast.  All went well.  6 sessions of FEC-T, lumpectomy and 4 weeks of radiotherapy.  I had a complete response to my treatment and have since had my first mammogram and every was clear!  You will get through it, I definitely found once the treatment started i just seemed to get on with it.  I wish you all the best. Alison
Posts.Title: Biopsy Results....... I'll be around for a while

Posts.Content: I have one very painful foot at the moment.  I finished chemo in July but did also suffer with it then. Making walking difficult.  Will look at the links. Alison xx
Posts.Title: Side effects of fec-t on feet and body

Posts.Content: Finished chemo in July.  Mine is curly, quite dark with grey highlights!  I've decided to not colour it and actually loving it! Always had long hair so this is a real change for me. Alison x
Posts.Title: Curly Hair!

Posts.Content: Hi I'm currently one week into 4 weeks of radiotherapy.  This is following 6 sessions of chemo and lumpectomy.  Fortunately I had a complete response to my treatment.  I was 50 this year and they keep telling me I'm young! I have taken everything they have offered me.  As for chemo I had FEC-T. I only really struggled on the last two but I think I was just exhausted by then. Wasn't sick at all. Once my hair was gone I felt so much better. it's all growing back now my last chemo was July.  I actually quite like my new hair! All the best for whatever you decide.  I was diagnosed in March and couldn't imagine Christmas but we are nearly there and I'm still here, a much stronger person with a completely different outlook on life.  Take care,  Alison x
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and should I have chemo?

Posts.Content: My hospital sorted mine.  It was a really good service and free.  My round trip was over 100 miles a day.  Actually made friends with other patients and stayed in touch.  xxx
Posts.Title: Volunteer drivers

Posts.Content: Started tamoxifen early October.  My knees hurt and my feet, on the heels,  are sometimes very painful.  Anyone else had this? Thank-you,  Alison x
Posts.Title: Feet and knees!

Posts.Content: Thank-you.  My feet were also painful during my last 3 chemo's. Imagine allsorts!  Xx
Posts.Title: Feet and knees!

Posts.Content: I had my first year mammogram last month which came back clear thankfully.  Had chemo, lumpectomy and 4 weeks radiotherapy which ended in December.  Now on Tamoxifen. Following that I had painful knees then very painful feet and ankles.  Probably only just started walking properly about 3 weeks ago.  Also had pain around my shoulder blade.  Was told this could be a side effect from the radiotherapy.  Had a couple of massages and it did improve.  I am finding if I do jobs around the house etc i still suffer.  Mainly when I get to bed.  It is just a dull ache but enough to keep me awake.  I have googled this and sounds like Rotator Cuff?  Has anyone else had this? Thank you
Posts.Title: Aches and pains ....... still!!!

Posts.Content: Thank you all for the comments.  It's nice to know it's not just me! Going to see about having some physio I think.  X
Posts.Title: Aches and pains ....... still!!!

Posts.Content: I felt the same as you at the beginning.  My kids didn't want to be in the same room as me.  It does get easier and you will get through it.  My husband used to get cross with me for being on Google all the time.  I have today had my last radiotherapy and could never imagine this day. I was diagnosed in March.  Chemo, followed by surgery then 4 weeks of radio.  I hope you start to feel better soon.  Take care, Alison xx
Posts.Title: Depressed

Posts.Content: I only have 2 more sessions of radiotherapy and can't wait for Friday lunch time when its all finished. Its hard to believe I am here!  Our world was turned upside down on March 15th when I was diagnosed with Grade 3 invasive ductal carcinoma, 3.5cm,  zero lymph nodes.  I had 6 sessions of FEC-T, couldn't feel lump after the second one.  Hardest part was of course the hair loss but once it was gone I put my wig on and felt 100 times better. I went from wanting a bilateral mastectomy to just a lumpectomy in September and had a complete pathological response.  Started on Tamoxifen for 5 years and then will be switched to Anastrozole for a further 5.  Family history so had genetics test and luckily result was negative, relief as I have a 23 year old daughter. Its a long, hard journey but I have made it with the help and love of my wonderful family and friends.  I even managed to have an Afternoon Tea Party in August and raised £600 for Breast Cancer Research.  I will be continuing to do this every summer from now on. For all of you just starting on this journey, I wish you all the best and can only say by my experience you will get through it and probably end up  a stronger person, I definitely have. I would also like to thank this forum.  Its been so reassuring to be able to read stories of other women going through the same thing as me.  I won't be leaving! Good luck to all you lovely ladies on here. Take care, Alison x
Posts.Title: ALMOST DONE!

Posts.Content: Thank you.  Are you having 4 weeks?  Best of luck to you too xxx
Posts.Title: ALMOST DONE!

Posts.Content: So glad there was no cancer.  So hoping I get that result.  It's all so stressful and draining. Will keep everything crossed for you. Thank you for replying.  Keep in touch.  Alison x
Posts.Title: Date for scan

Posts.Content: Posted earlier this week about shoulder pain. Doctor thinks it's muscular but referred me back to hospital.  Oncologist has booked me in for a ct scan. Letter came today,  routine appointment 17th May.  I'm hoping this is a good sign that they are not overly concerned   Anyone else had similar? Alison x
Posts.Title: Date for scan

Posts.Content: Hi Happyoptimist I was diagnosed same time as you. I've just finished treatment.  Hope you are doing ok.  Alison x
Posts.Title: Thank you ALL

Posts.Content: My eyes are the same!  5 weeks post chemo and I think they are growing again.  Eyes constantly watering!  Feet are peeling aswell.  Finger nails are horrible and hair is just starting to grow, looks fluffy at the moment.!!
Posts.Title: eyebrows, eyelashes and lizard feet

Posts.Content: My son had is GCSE's during my chemo.  I actually feel it was a distraction for him.  He just gone on with revision.  I did let the school know, probably a good idea for you to do that. My kids are older but they certainly gave me a reason to fight! Take care, Alison x
Posts.Title: Children

Posts.Content: Thank you all!  I have today been for my pre op assessment.  I think I am leaning towards lumpectomy and radiotherapy especially has I have had a good response to the chemo.  Who knows though, might change my mind tomorrow!!! xxx
Posts.Title: Masectomy or lumpectomy? Advice please

Posts.Content: Following 6 sessions of FEC-T chemo I had an MRI and have been told I have had a complete response to the treatment - thankfully!  I am booked in for surgery on the 12th September and need to decide between a masectomy and reconstruction or lumpectomy followed by 3 weeks of radiotherapy.  I have had the gene test and luckily the results were negative.  I cannot decide which way to go.  My mind changes from day to day.  Any words of advice would be great! Thanks, Alison
Posts.Title: Masectomy or lumpectomy? Advice please

Posts.Content: I think its just that fact that the whole breast will be gone!  That was my first reaction when diagnosed. My son who is 16 has said he would rather I did this!  At the end of the day I know it is my decision.  I do think I am moving more towards lumpectomy but it changes every day!   Good luck with your surgery, I wish you well and a speedy recovery.   Alison x
Posts.Title: Masectomy or lumpectomy? Advice please

Posts.Content: For me reconstruction will mean an implant so keeping my nipple.  Lump was in the lower breast (ductal).  Lymph nodes were clear.  Gene test was for BRCA 1 and 2  as a history of breast cancer on my Dad's side of the family, plus I have a 22 year old daughter so was concerned for her aswell. How did you cope with the chemo? My last one hit really hard, still have aching muscles now.  Feel like I have been weight lifting and ran a marathon!!! Alison
Posts.Title: Masectomy or lumpectomy? Advice please

Posts.Content: Hello Mine was 3cm invasive ductal cancer.  Lump was very obvious and easy to feel.  I had chemo first to shrink tumour and neither myself or oncologist could feel lump after second session.  By the time I had completed the 6 nothing could be seen on the scan.  I had a lumpectomy in September and no living cancer cells were found.  Am now almost at the end of week 3 of radiotherapy then just one more week which is a boost.  This is where they aim at just the tumour site and not the whole breast. Wishing you all the luck.   Alison
Posts.Title: Large lumps
